revision.text:
{{coord|59|14|09|N|16|49|17|E|region:SE_type:landmark|display=title}} '''Stålboga Summer Opera''' (Swedish: '''Stålboga sommaropera''') is an annual event staged at the privately owned Stålboga Manor House on a small peninsula in the lake Eklången 35 kilometers from [[Eskilstuna]] and 100 kilometers from [[Stockholm]], Sweden.
==Mill and manor house== [[File:Stålboga Herrgård.jpg|right|thumb|Stålboga manor house 2014. Photo by Nils Juto.]] Stålboga was a well known farm back in the 15th century. In 1560, the farm is included on the road map commissioned by king [[Gustav I of Sweden]]. On the earliest known detailed map of the province of [[Södermanland]] (Behmebergkartan) from 1625 Stålboga is indicated as an iron mill. Stålboga Mill was officially founded in 1641 and the mansion was erected around this time. On 17 September 1650 [[Christina, Queen of Sweden]] issued a nobility letter for Stålboga Mill, which included tax exemption. The preserved document is issued on parchment with a large royal seal. From the late 17th century the land area of the property was approximately 5,000 hectares, with its own blast furnace and iron mine. The mansion burned down in 1870 and was not rebuilt until 1984-85.<ref name="dunker">{{cite web |url=http://www.dunker.nu/Stalbogabruk.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160908184024/http://www.dunker.nu/Stalbogabruk.htm |title=Stålboga bruk |publisher=Dunker Parish database |language=Swedish |archivedate=2016-09-08 |accessdate=2016-09-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
The mill operation included [[rod iron]] forging, Lancashire [[pig iron]], cannons and cannonballs, and carriages. A [[rolling mill]] was erected in the 19th century, and a railway station on the Stockholm to Eskilstuna line was built in the 1890s to promote goods transport from the mill. Mill operations stopped in the 1890s. The forest company [[Holmen (company)|Holmen]] bought Stålboga in 1910.<ref name="dunker"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hembygd.se/malmkoping/har-verkar-var-forening/dunkers-socken |title=Dunkers socken |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160908184025/http://www.hembygd.se/malmkoping/har-verkar-var-forening/dunkers-socken |publisher=Sveriges Hembygdsförbund |language=Swedish |archivedate=2016-09-08 |accessdate=2016-09-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
Dr. Juto and his wife Dr. Maria Juto, who died in 2011, bought the central part of the estate with 500 hectares in 1979. They bought and moved the 1680s Tunafors mansion house from Eskilstuna and placed it on the old Stålboga foundation.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mynewsdesk.com/se/groena-kusten/pressreleases/aarets-soermlaenning-2011-685134 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160908184028/http://www.mynewsdesk.com/se/groena-kusten/pressreleases/aarets-soermlaenning-2011-685134 |title=Årets Sörmlänning 2011 |publisher=Gröna Kusten |language=Swedish |archivedate=2016-09-08 |accessdate=2016-09-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
==Music pavilion== [[File:Stålboga Paviljong.jpg|right|thumb|Stålboga pavilion 2014. Photo by Nils Juto.]] Dr. Juto, [[ophthalmologist]] and an avid classical music fan, decided in 2005 to build a music [[pavilion]] on the Stålboga premises with the idea of staging intimate music events of the highest possible standard. As a starting point Dr. Juto was able to acquire the late 18th century [[state room]] interiors of the [[De Geer]] family's great city palace in Stockholm, razed in 1926 to make way for the new headquarters of Swedish industrialist [[Ivar Kreuger|Ivar Kreuger's]] match business, the predecessor of [[Swedish Match]]. The interiors were designed by the same interior designers that were at the same time designing the interior of the [[Stockholm Palace|Royal Palace]] in Stockholm: [[Jean Eric Rehn]], [[Jean Baptiste Masreliez]], [[Adrien Masreliez]], [[Christoffer Gjörwell]] and [[Nicodemus Tessin the Elder]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stalbogabruk.se/paviljong/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160905184455/http://www.stalbogabruk.se/paviljong/ |publisher=Stålboga Bruk |title=Paviljongen |language=Swedish |archivedate=2016-09-05 |accessdate=2016-09-05 |deadurl=no }}</ref> At the time of construction of the music pavilion the interior decorations had then been stored for 80 years at the De Geer family's estate at [[Lövstabruk]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sormlandsbygden.se/2011/09/arets-sormlanning-fran-stalboga-bruk/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160905190712/http://sormlandsbygden.se/2011/09/arets-sormlanning-fran-stalboga-bruk/ |title=Årets Sörmlänning från Stålboga bruk |author=Helena Wistrand |publisher=Sörmlandsbygden |language=Swedish |date=1 September 2011 |archivedate=2016-09-05 |accessdate=2016-09-05|deadurl=no }}</ref>
The exterior of the music pavilion is inspired by the [[orangerie]] at the [[Ulriksdal Palace]] and [[Gustav III's Pavilion]], both near Stockholm.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.knorring.se/stalboga.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160908184028/http://www.knorring.se/stalboga.htm |title=Stålboga, Flen, Fest- och musikpaviljong |publisher=Peter von Knorring arkitektkontor |language=Swedish |archivedate=2016-09-08 |accessdate=2016-09-08 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
The pavilion was built by the same carpenters who rebuilt the dome of [[Katarina Church]] in Stockholm after the fire in 1990, with Swedish timber from [[Dalarna]] using 18th century methods, including hand forged nails. The pavilion was developed with advice from the company responsible for the acoustics of the [[Gothenburg Opera]].
==Summer opera== [[File:Cosi fan tutte opera.jpg|right|thumb|Cosí fan tutte, 7 September 2014]] [[File:Stalboga exterior.jpg|thumb|Stålboga pavilion 15 August 2015; intermission]] The Summer Opera started in 2013 as an independent project sponsored by Dr. Juto, the owner of the Stålboga Manor House. The opera concept usually includes dinner and wine in the ticket price.
Given the limited size of the music pavilion, the total number of singers cannot readily exceed ten at the most. Also, the space available for the orchestra is very limited. Management has therefore chosen a repertoire with limited cast and orchestra requirements, and has strived to find plots that harmonize with the intimate character of the 17th century interior. For the first seasons the orchestral part has been played on piano and cembalo, with the piano confined to [[aria]]s and the cembalo used for the [[recitative]].<ref name="operapågång">{{cite web |url=http://ekuriren.se/kulturnoje/1.1888400-opera-pa-gang-i-paviljong |archive-url=https://archive.is/20140907162306/http://ekuriren.se/kulturnoje/1.1888400-opera-pa-gang-i-paviljong |archive-date=7 September 2014 |title=Opera på gång i paviljong |author=Therése Norén |publisher=Eskilstuna-Kuriren |language=Swedish |date=26 August 2013 |accessdate=7 September 2014 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
The productions at Stålboga have included opera singers such as soprano [[Hillevi Martinpelto]], mezzo [[Katarina Karnéus]], the 1995 winner of the biennial [[BBC Cardiff Singer of the World competition]], and the young rising star baritone [[Luthando Qave]] who made his [[Metropolitan Opera|Metropolitan]] debut at age 25.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.neue-stimmen.de/en/history/all-participants/participants-a-to-z/details/269/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160905190132/http://www.neue-stimmen.de/en/history/all-participants/participants-a-to-z/details/269/ |publisher=Neue Stimme |title=Luthando Qave |archivedate=2016-09-05 |accessdate=2016-09-05 |deadurl=no }}</ref> The director for the first productions was the former Opera Director of [[Drottningholm Palace Theatre]], [[Per-Erik Öhrn]].<ref name="operapågång"/> In 2016 the Director was [[Mattias Ermedahl]] who is also a soloist [[baryton]] at [[GöteborgsOperan]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.opera.se/om-oss/personal/portratt/mattias-ermedahl/ |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160905185436/http://en.opera.se/om-oss/personal/portratt/mattias-ermedahl/ |publisher=GöteborgsOperan |title=Mattias Ermedahl |archivedate=2016-09-05 |accessdate=2016-09-05 |deadurl=no }}</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" !Year !Opera !Composer !Director |- |2013 |''[[Don Giovanni]]'' |[[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] |[[Per-Erik Öhrn]] |- |2014 |''[[Così fan tutte]]'' |[[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] |[[Per-Erik Öhrn]] |- |2015 |''[[Così fan tutte]]'' |[[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] |[[Per-Erik Öhrn]] |- |2016 |''[[La Serva Padrona]]/ [[Dido and Aeneas]]'' |[[Giovanni Battista Pergolesi]]/ [[Henry Purcell]] |[[Mattias Ermedahl]] |- |}
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.stalbogabruk.se}} (in Swedish) *[https://sv-se.facebook.com/pages/St%C3%A5lboga-Paviljong/721472371253488 Swedish Facebook site]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stalboga Summer Opera}} [[Category:Opera festivals]] [[Category:Opera houses in Sweden]] [[Category:Music festivals in Sweden]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Södermanland County]]

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/2600:1:C774:6653:E532:D40D:27C7:1EDE|2600:1:C774:6653:E532:D40D:27C7:1EDE]] ([[User talk:2600:1:C774:6653:E532:D40D:27C7:1EDE|talk]]) to last version by KolbertBot
revision.text:
[[File:Logo - The Art of Video Games - Smithsonian American Art Museum.jpg|thumb|''The Art of Video Games'' premiered at the Smithsonian American Art Museum in 2012.]] {{Art and video games}} '''''The Art of Video Games''''' was an exhibition by the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]] which was on display from March 16, 2012 through September 30, 2012. The exhibition was designed to highlight the evolution of art within the [[video game]] medium over its forty-year history. Following its time at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, the exhibition toured to 10 additional venues in the United States. [[Chris Melissinos]], founder of Past Pixels and collector of video games and gaming systems, was the curator of the exhibition. ==Purpose== ''The Art of Video Games''Smithsonian American Art Museum, The Art of Video Games, http://americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games was one of the first exhibitions to explore the forty-year evolution of video games as an artistic medium, with a focus on striking visual effects and the creative use of new technologies. It featured some of the most influential artists and designers during five eras of game technology, from early pioneers to contemporary designers (see grid below). The exhibition focused on the interplay of graphics, technology and storytelling through some of the best games for twenty gaming systems ranging from the Atari VCS to the PlayStation 3. ==Public vote== The Smithsonian American Art Museum invited the public to help select the video games to be included in the exhibition. The 240 games on the ballot were selected by [[Chris Melissinos]], who worked with the museum and an advisory group consisting of game developers, designers, industry pioneers, and journalists. The games were selected based on a variety of criteria, including visual effects, creative use of new technologies, and how the game fit into the narrative of the exhibition. Voting took place between February 14 and April 17, 2011. More than 3.7 million votes were cast by 119,000 people in 175 countries. ==Galleries== Visitors to ''The Art of Video Games'' at the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]] were greeted by a 12-foot projection that included excerpts from most of the 80 games featured in the exhibition with a chipmusic soundtrack written and recorded by [[8 Bit Weapon]] and [[ComputeHer]]. An interior gallery included a series of short videos showing the range of emotional responses players of all ages have while interacting with games. Five themed videos addressing the themes of Beginnings, Inspiration, Narrative, Experience and The Future showcased excerpts from interviews with 20 influential figures in the gaming world—[[Nolan Bushnell]], [[David Cage]], [[Steve Cartwright]], [[Jenova Chen]], [[Don Daglow]], [[Noah Falstein]], [[Ed Fries]], [[Ron Gilbert]], [[Robin Hunicke]], [[Henry Jenkins]], [[Jennifer MacLean]], [[RJ Mical]], [[Mike Mika]], [[David Perry (game developer)|David Perry]], [[Jane Pinckard]], George L. Rose, [[Kellee Santiago]], [[Tim Schafer]], [[Jesse Schell]], [[Warren Spector]] and [[Tommy Tallarico]]. The videos are also available on the museum’s website.Smithsonian American Art Museum, Exhibition Videos, ''The Art of Video Games'', {{cite web |url=http://americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/artists/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629123332/http://americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/artists/ |archivedate=2017-06-29 |df= }} (retrieved 4-3-2012) A five-channel installation displaying advances in core mechanics illustrated how home video games have evolved dramatically since their introduction in the 1970s through elements like avatars, jumping, running, climbing, flying, cutscenes and landscapes Smithsonian American Art Museum, ''The Art of Video Games'', {{cite web |url=http://americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/mechanics |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120511072009/http://www.americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/mechanics/ |archivedate=2012-05-11 |df= }}. The room also held a selection of concept art from several games of different eras. Five playable games, one from each era, showed how players interact with diverse virtual worlds, highlighting innovative techniques that set the standard for many subsequent games. The playable games were [[Pac-Man]], [[Super Mario Brothers]], [[The Secret of Monkey Island]], [[Myst]], and [[Flower (video game)]]. Interactive kiosks in the final gallery covered five eras of game technology, from early pioneers to contemporary designers, and 20 gaming systems from Ataric VCS to PlayStation 3. Each kiosk featured a game from each of four genres—action, target, adventure and tactics—that visitors could select to listen to commentary, game dialogue and music. ==Games exhibited== [[File:The art of video games exhibition crowd.jpg|thumb|Visitors at the exhibit during its opening weekend at the Smithsonian American Art Museum]] The following list of games are those that were selected by Melissinos and the advisory board for inclusion in the exhibition. The exhibition is divided into five chronological eras, showcasing platforms from within that era. For each platform, three games from each of four game genres were initially selected for inclusion, with one game determined by the public voting to be part of the final exhibition. In addition, playable versions of five games are available: ''[[Pac-Man]]'', ''[[Super Mario Bros.]]'', ''[[The Secret of Monkey Island]]'', ''[[Myst]]'', and ''[[Flower (video game)|Flower]]''.Smithsonian American Art Museum, ''The Art of Video Games'', Featured Games, {{cite web |url=http://americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/featuredgames/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-12-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203152720/http://americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/featuredgames// |archivedate=2016-12-03 |df= }} ===Era 1: Start! | 2009 |- | ''[[Sid Meier's Civilization Revolution]]'' | 2008 |} ==Subsequent exhibitions== Following its time at the Smithsonian, the exhibit was also shown at ten other venues across the United States, between 2013 and 2016. *[[Smithsonian American Art Museum]] in Washington, D.C. (March 16, 2012 – September 30, 2012) *[[Boca Raton Museum of Art]] in Boca Raton, Florida (October 24, 2012 – January 13, 2013) *[[EMP Museum]] in Seattle, Washington (February 16, 2013 – May 13, 2013) *[[Phoenix Art Museum]] in Phoenix, Arizona (June 16, 2013—September 29, 2013) *[[Everson Museum of Art]] in Syracuse, New York (October 25, 2013 – January 19, 2014) *[[Hudson River Museum]] in Yonkers, New York (February 15, 2014 – May 18, 2014) *[[Toledo Museum of Art]] in Toledo, Ohio (June 19, 2014 – September 28, 2014) *[[Flint Institute of Arts]] in Flint, Michigan (October 25, 2014 – January 18, 2015) *[[Chrysler Museum of Art]] in Norfolk, Virginia (February 13, 2015 – May 10, 2015) *[[Memphis Brooks Museum of Art]] in Memphis, Tennessee (June 6, 2015 – September 13, 2015) *The Patricia and Phillip [[Frost Art Museum]] at Florida International University in Miami, Florida (October 9, 2015 – January 25, 2016) ==Book== A companion book, ''The Art of Video Games: From Pac-Man to Mass Effect'', accompanies the exhibition. It is written by [[Chris Melissinos]], with a foreword by Elizabeth Broun, director of the Smithsonian American Art Museum and an introduction by Mike Mika, head of development for Other Ocean Interactive and a prominent advocate for the preservation of video game history. It also includes more than 100 composite images of games created by Patrick O’Rourke. The book, published by Welcome Books in cooperation with the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]], is available online and at bookstores nationwide (hardcover, $40).Welcome Books, http://www.welcomebooks.com/artofvideogames/ ==Reception== {{rewrite section|date=December 2012}} An estimated 680,000 visitors came to the Smithsonian exhibit during its six-month display period.{{Cite web | url = http://www.joystiq.com/2012/10/02/heres-how-many-people-saw-the-smithsonians-art-of-games/ | title = Here's how many people saw The Smithsonian's Art of Games | first = Jessica | last = Conditt | date = 2012-10-02 | accessdate = 2012-10-11 | publisher = [[Joystiq]] }} The following is a sample of media coverage of the exhibition: *Kohler, Chris. ''[[Salon (website)|Salon]]''. 10 March 2012. ==See also== *[[Game On (exhibition)|Game On]] - A similar exhibition that explores the historical development of video games. *[[Game Masters (exhibition)]] - A similar exhibition at the [[Australian Centre for the Moving Image]] that explores key designers of the video game medium. *[[List of video games in the Museum of Modern Art]] - a list of video games in a similar, but smaller exhibition of the [[Museum of Modern Art]]. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110806051435/http://americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/ Smithsonian American Art Museum ''The Art of Video Games'' exhibition information] *[http://www.artofvideogames.org/ ''The Art of Video Games'' voting site] *[http://www.americanart.si.edu/exhibitions/archive/2012/games/artists/ Curator interview, exhibition trailer and artist interviews] *[http://www.welcomebooks.com/artofvideogames/ ''The Art Of Video Games: From Pac-Man To Mass Effect'' book website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Art Of Video Games, The}} [[Category:Art exhibitions in the United States]] [[Category:Smithsonian Institution exhibitions]] [[Category:Video game exhibitions]] [[Category:Video gaming in the United States]]

{{Infobox music festival | music_festival_name = World Liberty Concert | image = [[File:World Liberty Concert logo, as broadcasted live May 1995.jpg|250px]] | caption = The logo of the World Liberty Concert, as broadcast live. | location = {{Interlanguage link multi|Stadsblokken|2=nl|3=Stadsblokken-Meinerswijk#Stadsblokken|preserve=1}}, [[Arnhem]], [[Netherlands]] | years_active = 1995 | founders = [[Arno Geul]]
[[Alan Parsons]] | dates = May 8, 1995 | genre = [[Rock music]]
[[Pop music]] }} [[File:Overview of the festival terrain during the World Liberty Concert, as broadcasted live on televion on May 8th, 1995.jpg|thumb|Overview of the concert, showing the stage next to the bridge.]]The '''World Liberty Concert''' was a concert that took place on May 8, 1995 next to the [[John Frost Bridge]] in [[Arnhem]] in the [[Netherlands]]. The concert was held in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of the liberation of Europe and is the largest memorial concert ever held in the Netherlands and was thought of by [[Arno Geul]].{{cite web |url=http://www.roadkill.com/APP/faq/#3.03 |title=The Alan Parsons Project List of Frequently Asked Questions: Okay, then what is the World Liberty Concert? |website=Roadkill Consulting |date=September 1996 |accessdate=2014-01-25}} Preparations lasted for about a year.{{cite web |url=http://www.theproductionfactory.eu/en/projects/world-liberty-concert |title=World Liberty Concert |website=The Production Factory |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} Performances were provided by [[Alan Parsons]] (with [[Chris Thompson (English musician)|Chris Thompson]] and [[Michael J. Mullins|Mick Mullins]]), [[Art Garfunkel]], [[Joe Cocker]], [[Cyndi Lauper]], [[Wet Wet Wet]], [[Candy Dulfer]], [[UB40]] and [[René Froger]]. Also present was the [[Metropole Orkest]] consisting of 80 men and the [[Gelders Opera and Operetta Gezelschap|Gelders Opera and Operetta Gezelschap (GOOG)]] choir. The event-specific configuration of [[The Alan Parsons Project]], which had been a studio group only, was one of the first ever live performances of the band's material, albeit without cofounder [[Eric Woolfson]]; it was performed under the name of [[Alan Parsons Band]].{{cite web |url=http://alanparsons-project.blogspot.com/2011/02/bootleg-alan-parsons-band-metropol.html |title=THE ALAN PARSONS PROJECT: BOOTLEG: Alan Parsons Band, The Metropole Orchestra, Choir & Guests - 1995-05-08 - Arnhem, NL |website=THE ALAN PARSONS PROJECT |date=2011-02-19 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} The musical performances were accompanied by historical readings by [[Walter Cronkite]] and an illustrative performance by the [[Royal Netherlands Army]]. The broadcast portion of the concert lasted about 2 hours, was attended by 85,000 people and was broadcast in 45 countries, of which 31 were live. The entire concert lasted over 12 hours. == Evening Concert == The evening concert was broadcast live and was initiated by a seven-and-a-half-minute introduction, showing the various preparations for the concert. The video featured a medley of classical songs of the soundtrack of the movie [[Glory (1989 film)#Soundtrack|Glory]]. In total, the evening concert covered 21 songs: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Artists !! Song !! Notes |- | [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]], [[Metropole Orkest]], [[Gelders Opera and Operetta Society]] || [[World Liberty Theme]] || [[Walter Cronkite]] makes his appearance at the broadcast during this song. |- | [[Metropole Orkest]], [[Gelders Opera and Operetta Society]] || (unnamed) || Quite a dramatical classical piece, accompanying the invasion by the aggressor (dressed in brown). |- | [[Joe Cocker]], [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]], [[Metropole Orkest]] || [[Have a Little Faith (Joe Cocker album)|Let The Healing Begin]] || Imagery of the [[Normandy landings]] is shown during the song. |- | [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]], [[Metropole Orkest]] || [[Sirius (song)|Sirius]] || At the beginning of the song an [[Civil defense siren|Air alarm]] is run for a couple of swoops. |- | [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]], [[Candy Dulfer]], [[Metropole Orkest]] || [[Try Anything Once|Breakaway]] || Fireworks were lit halfway down the song. |- | [[Cindi Lauper]] || [[Time After Time (Cyndi Lauper song)|Time After Time]] || Old video material of WWII paratroopers is shown. Near the concert's location voluntary parachutists are coming down. |- | [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]], [[Metropole Orkest]], [[Gelders Opera and Operetta Society]] || White Dawn || The allied forces presents themselves (dressed in white) and capture the aggressor at the bridge. |- | [[UB40]] || [[Sing Our Own Song]] || |- | [[René Froger]], [[Metropole Orkest]] || [[Thunder in My Heart (song)|Thunder in My Heart]] || |- | [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]], [[Candy Dulfer]] || [[Old and Wise]] || |- | [[UB40]] || [[Many Rivers to Cross]] || |- | [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]], [[Candy Dulfer]] || [[The Turn of a Friendly Card|The Gold Bug]] || On the Rhine rubber boats of the Army make circles, while carrying flags of the [[United Nations]]. On the bridge young female performers wave the flags of the United Nations in a choreographed manner. |- | [[Cindi Lauper]] || [[True Colors (Cyndi Lauper song)|True Colors]] || Rubber boats of the army cross the Rhine. |- | [[Wet Wet Wet]], [[Metropole Orkest]] || [[Love Is All Around (The Troggs song)|Love Is All Around]] || |- | [[Candy Dulfer]] || [[I Can't Make You Love Me|I Can't Make You Love Me (Instrumental)]] || |- | [[Joe Cocker]], [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]] || [[With a Little Help from My Friends]] || |- | [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]], [[Metropole Orkest]] || [[Sirius (song)|The Dream of Peace (Sirius Reprise)]] || Fireworks were lit halfway down the song. |- | [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]], [[Metropole Orkest]] || [[Eye in the Sky (song)|Eye in the Sky]] || A helicopter hovered above the Rhine. |- | [[Wet Wet Wet]], [[Metropole Orkest]] || [[Julia Says]] || |- | [[Chris Thompson (English musician)|Chris Thompson]], [[The Alan Parsons Project|Alan Parsons Band]], [[Metropole Orkest]] || [[You're the Voice]] || Volunteers held burning torches at the side of the Rhine, which was also decorated by spraying water fountains. |- | [[Art Garfunkel]] || [[Bridge over Troubled Water (song)|Bridge over Troubled Water]] || The end of the song was accompanied by fireworks. |} === Narrative === [[File:Walter Cronkite narrating the World Liberty Concert, as broadcasted on television on May 8th, 1995.jpg|thumb|right|[[Walter Cronkite]] as he appeared during the television broadcast of the concert.]] During the concert, [[Walter Cronkite]] [[Narrative|narrated]] parts of history during and after the [[World War II|Second World War]], in order to illustrate the historical meaning of the concert. During the concert Walter Cronkite was positioned at the side of the Rhine, in a military [[Jeep]]. In his initial appearance at the beginning of the concert, [[Walter Cronkite]] both describes the reason for his presence and the reason for the concert:
I am here tonight, because as a [[war correspondent]], I was part of the [[Operation Market Garden|allied airborne operation]] that for a brief moment in history, more than fifty years ago, focused the world's attention on this [[John Frost Bridge|crossing of the Rhine]] and this Dutch City of [[Arnhem]]. I speak tonight from hallowed ground, for here more than 1500 brave [[Parachute Regiment (United Kingdom)|British parachutists]] died in a futile attempt to gain the bridge. 6000 were captured, many of them wounded. They represent for us tonight, the millions of others, soldiers, sailors, airmen and civilians, claimed in [[World War II|history’s worst calamity]]. In a war whose long delayed ending, this concert commemorates and celebrates. In May 1944 the [[Europe|European continent]] had been a major battleground for almost four years. The country's provinces, cities and more importantly the people of Europe were devastated by the toll of mankind’s [[World War II|Second World War]]. Beginning just 50 kilometers upstream from this City of [[Arnhem]], stretched the heartland of the aggressor's war industry. While the sounds of the factories were of course too far off to be heard from here, life was dominated by the ominous sound of a not so distant thunder.
In total, [[Walter Cronkite]] makes 11 appearances during the concert, covering the history in chronological order: # Introduction and description of the situation of the region in 1944. # Description of the [[Normandy landings]], and the significance of [[D-Day (military term)|D-Day]] as a turning point. # [[Arnhem]] and its Rhine bridge was becoming a strategic focal point in the summer of 1944, which caused preparations for an operation to be made. # Paratroops were dropped in [[Operation Market Garden]], but the effort failed. # The defeat during [[Operation Market Garden]] destroyed the hopes and the city of [[Arnhem]]. # On may 5th 1945, the [[Netherlands]] were liberated and three days later the peeace treaty was signed. # In June 1945 the [[United Nations]] was established, to maintain international peace and security. # In 1995 the benefits of the [[United Nations]] are visible to us all. # The [[European Union]] is a new reality and a growing world power. # Much work is being done by organizations such as [[UNICEF]], for the youth of today, the world leaders of tomorrow. # It is up to the next generation to accomplish world peace, which the current generation has failed to accomplish. == Releases == The evening concert was supposed to be released as video and CD. A legal dispute made only a single, ''[[You're the Voice]]'',{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/Alan-Parsons-Youre-The-Voice/release/4232878 |title= Alan Parsons – You're The Voice |website=Discogs |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}}{{cite web |url=http://www.goog.nl/historie-van-het-goog/historie-van-het-goog |title=Historie van het GOOG |website=Gelders Opera en Operette Gezelschap |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}} be released, which included the live recording of White Dawn{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=odnv2kaBAbg |title=WHITE DAWN |website=YouTube |date=2010-08-10 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} and a studio recording of [[You're the Voice]].{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PwuQWEwc9fw |title=Alan Parsons - You're The Voice - (Audio Lyrics) - 1995 |website=YouTube |date=2010-05-18 |accessdate=2014-01-26}}{{cite web |url=http://www.roadkill.com/APP/faq/#3.03 |title=The Alan Parsons Project List of Frequently Asked Questions: What is "White Dawn"? |website=Roadkill Consulting |date=September 1996 |accessdate=2014-01-25}}{{cite web |url=http://www.onlinemusicdatabase.com/comments.phtml/7403 |title=Comments for Parsons, Alan, From the World Liberty Concert: You're the Voice-White Dawn |website=WWW Music Database |date= |accessdate=2014-01-26}} Despite the lack of a full release, bootlegs of the broadcast are circulating.{{cite web |url=http://www.theavenueonline.info/site1/app-faq.htm#live_videos |title=Alan Parsons FAQ: Can I buy videos of live performances? |website=The Avenue Online |date=2006 |accessdate=2014-01-26}} The studio recording of You're the Voice was featured on [[The Very Best of: Live]] in the same year as well, albeit in a longer (no radio edit) version.{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/Alan-Parsons-The-Very-Best-Live/release/4232605 |title= Alan Parsons – The Very Best Live (CD, Album) |website=Discogs |date= |accessdate=2014-01-25}} ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Category:Concerts]] [[Category:1995 in the Netherlands]]
